channel.title: Experience with Linux
channel.description: All about Linux and all about the experiences

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
You might wanna ask me that in spite of having hundreds (probably more than that) of open source software blogs out there why a new one altogether? I know. But I'll tell you why, this blog is purely created to share my experiences while using Linux. There won't be any bias towards any software, programming language or anything. But only what I feel would be helpful to beginners to start their experiences with.
Come aboard and let's start this journey of knowing Linux!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
I am a linux enthusiast and like to explore the many worlds of linux. This blog is an attempt toÂ  contribute to the linux community my experiences!
Kudos!

item.title: WPForms Preview
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
This is the WPForms preview page. All your form previews will be handled on this page.

The page is set to private, so it is not publicly accessible. Please do not delete this page :) .

item.title: Linux flavors - sweet, sour & spicy!
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
One of the most confusing things for the newcomers to Linux is how many distributions, or flavors are there. Ubuntu is the one most people have heard of, but there are hundreds (literally!) of others as well, each offering some variant based on the basic Linux kernel What follows, is a short summary of the best Linux distributions I liked so far. Linux - Mint Linux Mint is a community-driven Linux distribution based on Debian and Ubuntu that strives to be a "modern, elegant and comfortable operating system which is both powerful and easy to use."
The reason mint is on top of my list is because of the ease of use and huge customization availability compared to other flavors.
Mint works great with cinnamon desktop environment which is based on Gnome 3 (Gnome 3 is pretty good itself, but I'll save that debate for later!). Cinnamon is friendly to the native Windows users who have switched to open source.
So, overall Mint is the sweetest distro available.
Ubuntu
Based on Debian, Ubuntu is published by Canonical Ltd, who offer commercial support. It is based on free software and named after the Southern African philosophy of ubuntu (literally, 'human-ness'), which Canonical Ltd. suggests can be loosely translated as "humanity to others" or "I am what I am because of who we all are"
Ubuntu has a wide application over technology. From Cloud computing to managing servers, containers, IoT and many more. We will focus on the desktop edition of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 17.10 comes with Unity8 and Ubuntu default desktop environments. Unity8 is a treat for UI/UX lovers and one should definitely try it once. Though Linux Mint and Ubuntu are almost same. Ubuntu is a step back from Linux when it comes to execution time.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: A homepage section
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded: This is an example of a homepage section. Homepage sections can be any page other than the homepage itself, including the page that shows your latest blog posts.

item.title: Linux flavors - sweet, sour & spicy!

One of the most confusing things for the newcomers to Linux is how many distributions, or flavors are there. Ubuntu is the one most people have heard of, but there are hundreds (literally!) of others as well, each offering some variant based on the basic Linux kernel
What follows, is a short summary of the best Linux distributions I liked so far.

item.title: Linux Mint
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
Linux Mint is a community-driven Linux distribution based on Debian and Ubuntu that strives to be a "modern, elegant and comfortable operating system which is both powerful and easy to use."
The reason mint is on top of my list is because of the ease of use and huge customization availability compared to other flavors.
Mint works great with cinnamon desktop environment which is based on Gnome 3 (Gnome 3 is pretty good itself, but I'll save that debate for later!). Cinnamon is friendly to the native Windows users who have switched to open source.
So, overall Mint is the sweetest distro available.

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: sujay
item.content:encoded:
Based on Debian, Ubuntu is published by Canonical Ltd, who offer commercial support. It is based on free software and named after the Southern African philosophy of ubuntu (literally, 'human-ness'), which Canonical Ltd. suggests can be loosely translated as "humanity to others" or "I am what I am because of who we all are"
Ubuntu has a wide application over technology. From Cloud computing to managing servers, containers, IoT and many more. We will focus on the desktop edition of Ubuntu. Ubuntu 17.10 comes with Unity8 and Ubuntu default desktop environments. Unity8 is a treat for UI/UX lovers and one should definitely try it once. Though Linux Mint and Ubuntu are almost same. Ubuntu is a step back from Linux when it comes to execution time.
